There was a paperweight, a slice of agate with a fossilized fern inside it, leaves etched white from 300 million years of pressure. She didn\u2019t look long. \u201cWhy did you think you could get away with it.\u201d\n\n\u201cBecause I\u2019ve gotten away with things that mattered more,\u201d Julian said, and his mouth tilted a fraction, not as humor. \u201cBecause storms wash prints. Because lawyers make doubt. Because in this house if you keep your voice level and your hands still, people mistake you for the adult in the room.\u201d\n\nRourke let the quiet sit until it found its edges. Outside, the wind hunted along the clapboards and moved on.\n\n\u201cSay the words,\u201d Rourke said. \u201cFor the record.\u201d\n\nJulian nodded once, a man stepping into the exact outline of his crime. \u201cI destroyed portions of a testamentary instrument,\u201d he said. \u201cI tore and burned will pages to prevent their effect on existing trusts.\u201d\n\n\u201cKnowingly.\u201d\n\n\u201cYes.\u201d\n\n\u201cVoluntarily.\u201d\n\n\u201cYes.\u201d\n\n\u201cWithout permission.\u201d\n\n\u201cObviously.\u201d\n\nMara didn\u2019t flinch. \u201cWho drafted the shell trusts.\u201d\n\n\u201cWardell & Pratt for the initial frames. Maintenance moved to a boutique in Boston when the optics went bad\u2014Halden Street Advisors. They act like a family office but they\u2019re a laundromat with mahogany paneling.\u201d\n\n\u201cBeneficiaries on paper,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cCousins and a foundation named for a seaside bird. The distributions land elsewhere. None of this is a revelation to anyone who looks long enough.\u201d\n\nRourke flipped a page on his pad. His handwriting was blocky, not the neat print he used on evidence seals. \u201cPotential charges I\u2019m noting for the file,\u201d he said, as if Julian had asked for a rundown: \u201cDestruction of a testamentary document, tampering with evidence, obstruction. If any of those trusts touched public money or fraud, there\u2019s a wire angle. I\u2019m not your counsel. You\u2019re not under arrest right now. You should know what I\u2019m hearing.\u201d\n\nJulian\u2019s chin lifted a fraction, then fell back to neutral. \u201cUnderstood.\u201d\n\n\u201cWho has the original will,\u201d Mara asked.\n\n\u201cVivian\u2019s counsel in town. The draft matched the last filed will with the exceptions I burned.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhere is the microcassette Ms. Hale used to dictate the codicil.\u201d\n\nJulian glanced, involuntary, at the case under Rourke\u2019s knee. \u201cI had it,\u201d he said. \u201cI tried to keep it. I did not succeed.\u201d\n\nRourke looked at him until he looked away. Then he checked the recorder\u2019s red eye, steady as a heartbeat. \u201cStatement is clean so far,\u201d he said to the machine. To Julian: \u201cAnything you want to add about why.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy father taught me money was a tide and we were the ones with the moon in our pocket,\u201d Julian said. \u201cThat\u2019s the kind of thing that sounds wise until you are ankle\u2011deep in black water in your own house, trying to decide whether to save paper or people.\u201d He exhaled. \u201cI chose paper. That is what I did.\u201d\n\nMara\u2019s pen stopped. She capped it. \u201cDid you ever tell Vivian you opposed the change.\u201d\n\n\u201cYes.\u201d\n\n\u201cHow did she respond.\u201d\n\n\u201cShe said I was confusing prudence with entitlement. She said legacies are not bins you empty into your children. She said she was tired.\u201d\n\n\u201cDid you argue.\u201d\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d he said. \u201cI said we\u2019d look at it after the storm.\u201d\n\nRourke tapped the recorder once with his knuckle, a soft cue. \u201cWe\u2019re going to wrap this pass and I\u2019m going to read it back,\u201d he said. \u201cThen you sign.\u201d\n\nJulian\u2019s mouth was dry. \u201cFine.\u201d\n\nRourke rewound, played the statement back in that metallic room\u2011tone that makes everyone sound like an actor learning to be ordinary. He slid the pad across. Julian read, took the pen, and signed with a signature that looked practiced even when his hand held a tremor.\n\nRourke dated it, initialed each page. He slotted the signed sheets into a clear envelope, peeled the seal, and smoothed it with the heel of his hand. I will also draft a preservation notice to all parties and the bank, freezing any movement in and out of the trusts pending hearing.   "final_scene": "The morning felt wrung-out. The light came pale and metallic off the water, as if the ocean had been hammered flat and left there to glint. Mara\u2019s boots made a sound like wet bread on the sodden path as she followed Rourke up toward the overlook. The wind moved in long, tired breaths. Gulls rode the lift along the cliff with the arrogance of birds that had slept well.\n\nRourke had his field jacket zipped to his throat. Salt had dried in a frost along the collar. He didn\u2019t look back as he climbed; he had the forward lean of someone who didn\u2019t trust the ground not to slide out from under his feet.\n\n\u201cWatch your left,\u201d he said. \u201cThe shoulder\u2019s gone soft.\u201d\n\nMara tested the edge with the tip of her boot. It gave, a mushy surrender, and she shifted back. \u201cSmells like a broken cellar.\u201d\n\n\u201cClay and rot,\u201d Rourke said.\n\nThey reached the wooden rail at the overlook\u2014a rail that had been two rails yesterday and now was one stuttering line. The second had been ripped free and sat thirty feet down on a ledge, speared into a tangle of thrift and blackberry like a dropped ladder. She measured the distance from the blistered post to the edge, wrote it down: twenty-seven inches. She measured the depth of a crack running parallel to the cliff, the start of a failure that had not yet finished failing. Less than a hand deep. Greenhouse remediation\u2014line item. Masonry repair\u2014line item. Professional cleanup\u2014line item.
